description: As a new user to linux - I find this easy to use - works well - very usefull - very configuarable - as a user that has been on the internet since april 1993 - focusing on security matters this app works well - 3 years on linux - anyone haveing issues with this, well, it works and works well - if you find it dosent from the short time useing linux I find you have to be particular how this is installed on certain distro's and what version you use - however - this is a very usefull tool. Thank you
I used Little Snitch for a decade and it was great. Definately had a lot of alerts until it was trained. OpenSnitch does absolutely nothing at all. Into the trash it goes.

I have had this app on Endeavour OS for over a year, and I has been working just fine. Now, I'm trying to install it on fedora 38, it does install, but never works. App doesn't even launch. Even after enabling the systemd service.

Cool tool, but very annoying for an advanced user. It pops up for every process that runs so it can be frustrating to manage. The plus side is that you can dissable it after the 100 pop-ups you get initially and then you can access the logs it made within the app. It does a good job of monitoring the DNS records of what's going on within your pc. Wouldn't recommend to someone developing an app for mass consumption or for a normal user.

Great when it works but having bought a new latop and installing Opensnitch onto Manjaro (Arch linux) it doesn't work. I can't get th GUI to start up, whereas it did on my old laptop. I may have a later version of Manjaro now.

Opensnitch works when I installed it from github https://github.com/evilsocket/opensnitch/wiki/Installation

Just follow the instructions carefully and you will have a working firewall in no time.
With this tool you can easily map out ALL the call outs from your PC to DNS. Giveing an oversight over just how invasive the google api is, f.ex.
summary: Great for oversight and monitoring your network traffic

description: Gestion par interface et système ainsi que les redirections ssh par exemple
